title: 106_hr1631
content: The Act titled "Make College Affordable Act of 1999" allows for a deduction for higher education expenses under Section 221 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act allows a deduction for qualified higher education expenses and interest on qualified higher education loans paid by the taxpayer during the taxable year. The deduction is subject to a limitation based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses and interest on qualified higher education loans is limited based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, which is calculated without certain deductions and after applying specific tax sections. For taxable years after 2000, the $65,000 and $95,000 amounts for deductions are adjusted annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. If the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $5,000, it is rounded down to the nearest multiple of $5,000. The amount for deductions is adjusted annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment and rounded down to the next lowest multiple of $5,000. Qualified higher education expenses include tuition and fees for the taxpayer, spouse, dependents, and grandchildren. The tax deduction for qualified higher education expenses includes tuition and fees for the taxpayer, spouse, dependents, and grandchildren, as well as reasonable living expenses for eligible students attending an institution of higher education. Amounts paid for eligible courses are taken into account for the deduction. The tax deduction for qualified higher education expenses includes tuition and fees for eligible students attending an institution of higher education. Eligible students must meet specific requirements outlined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. Nonacademic fees such as student activity fees, athletic fees, and insurance expenses are not included in the deduction. The tax deduction for qualified higher education expenses requires eligible students to be carrying at least half the normal full-time workload at an institution of higher education. Taxpayers must include the eligible student's name, age, and taxpayer identification number on their tax return to claim the deduction. The tax deduction for qualified higher education expenses requires eligible students to be carrying at least half the normal full-time workload at an institution of higher education. Eligible students must be described in the Higher Education Act of 1965 and eligible to participate in programs under title IV of the Act. A qualified higher education loan is defined as a loan made, insured, or guaranteed by the Federal Government, a State, a political subdivision of a State, from the proceeds of a qualified student loan bond, or by an institution of higher education. The tax deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to the amount of interest on a qualified higher education loan used for such expenses. No double benefit is allowed for any expense claimed under the deduction. The tax deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to the amount of interest on a qualified higher education loan used for such expenses. No double benefit is allowed for any expense claimed under the deduction, unless the taxpayer irrevocably waives the right to the deduction under another provision. Additionally, no deduction is allowed if the taxpayer elects to apply a different section for the individual's expenses or if a deduction is allowable to another taxpayer for the same individual. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to the amount exceeding exclusions under certain sections for the taxable year and is only allowed for expenses related to enrollment at an institution of higher education during that year. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to the amount exceeding exclusions under certain sections for the taxable year. Certain prepayments for qualified higher education expenses are not allowed if they are in connection with an academic term beginning during the taxable year or the first 3 months of the next taxable year. Additionally, the amount of qualified higher education expenses is reduced by certain scholarships and veterans benefits received for the taxable year. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to the amount exceeding exclusions under certain sections for the taxable year. No deduction is allowed for certain prepayments related to academic terms. Scholarships and veterans benefits received reduce the amount of qualified higher education expenses. Married individuals must file a joint return for the deduction to apply. Nonresident aliens are subject to specific rules regarding the deduction. The deduction for higher education expenses is limited to the amount exceeding exclusions for the taxable year. Nonresident aliens must be treated as resident aliens for the deduction to apply. The Secretary may prescribe regulations for this section. The table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code is amended by replacing section 221 with a new item. Section 221 of the Higher Education Expenses Code was amended to change a specific section reference. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 1998.
